name: mancozeb production | mancozeb | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7845/documentation

This dataset represents the production of mancozeb (1 kg of active ingredient). Raw materials are modelled with a stoichiometric calculation.  Energy consumption is modelled with data from a similar process. The emissions are estimated. Infrastructure is included with a default value.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of precursors (ammonia, carbon disulfide, ethylenediamide, hydrochloric acid, manganese concentrate, oxygen, sodium hydroxide, sulfur dioxide, and zinc) at the factory gate.

This activity ends with mancozeb at the factory gate. The dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions. The dataset doesn't include emulsives, additives etc.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Mancozeb is a pesticide produced in three steps from ethylene diamine:;C2H8N2 + 2 CS2 + 2 NaOH → C4H6N2S4Na2 + 2 H2O;C4H6N2S4Na2 + MnSO4 → C4H6N2S4Mn + Na2SO4;2 C4H6N2S4Mn + Zn(NO3)2 → C8H12N4S8MnZn + Mn(NO3)2;Precursors that are used for the mancozeb production are manganese sulfate (MnSO4) and zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2).;Manganese sulfate (MnSO4) is produced from manganese dioxide and sulfur dioxide: ;MnO2 + SO2 → MnSO4;Zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2) is produced in two steps from ammonia: ;4 NH3 + 5 O2 → 4 NO + 6 H2O;2 NO + O2 → N2O4

exchanges.description:
Mancozeb is a grayish-yellow powder with a musty odor which is practically insoluble in water as well as most organic solvents. It is a polymer of maneb combined with zinc. 
Mancozeb is stable under most conditions. It may burn, but does not readily ignite, and containers may explode in the heat of a fire. Thermal decomposition products may include toxic oxides of carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. Suspensions of mancozeb dust in the air can ignite or explode.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description: Estimation, assuming that the remaining amount of unreacted input materials leave the production process with the wastewater, wich is further treated in an internal wastewater plant. For the nitrogen containing compounds within the wastewater a removal efficiency of 50% was assumed. The nitrogen emitted to air (N2) is neglected.

flow.name: Ammonia
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from calculation of avarage consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ kg-1), and a resulting amount of heat of 2 MJ for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that inlcudes 12% steam from external energy sources.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:

Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

flow.name: Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from calculation of avarage consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ kg-1), and a resulting amount of electricity of 0,333 kW for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that inlcudes 38% electricity.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:

Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

flow.name: Carbon disulfide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on a production capacity of 50,000 t per year and a plant life time of 50 years, therefore an amount of 4X10-10 units per kg of produced chemical  is aded to the unit process of the respective chemical. The amount is accounted for each production step. This might be an overestimation in some multistep syntheses.

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on the assumption that 0.2% of volatile input materials is emitted to air occurring from the purge vent, the destillation vent and fugitive emission sources. Remaining gases like CH4 or CO are oxidated to CO2. The carbon contained in the removed carbon compounds from wastewater treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air (assuming  a removal efficiency of 90%).
